messageBody:
From: "Shane Duan" <sduan@...>
> So if I am going to spend a lot of time anyway, I'd rather refactor the code to make the testing easy, and improve the design on the way. I think this fits into 'simplest possible' principle also.

That sounds good to me. Often the trick is just to provide a level of indirection for getting hold of objects. For example, quite often we have multiple constructors -- one with parameters to allow you pass in mock instances, and another one that calls it that provides default implementations:


class Thing {
public Thing(Param1 aParam) {
self(aParam, new RealObject());
}
public Thing(Param1 aParam, Realnterface aReal) {
param = aParam;
real = aReal;
}
[...]
}

The other one we use a lot is lazy construction. Create an instance of the real object if you haven't already preloaded a mock one.

Steve
